question: 6 (b)
statement_html: Let a and b denote positive integers. Let m denote the least common multiple of a and b, and let d denote the greatest common divisor of a and b. Then show that \(\displaystyle ab = md\). (Hint: use the prime factorization of a and b.)
statement_latex:
Let \emph{a} and \emph{b} denote positive integers. Let \emph{m} denote
the least common multiple of \emph{a} and \emph{b}, and let \emph{d}
denote the greatest common divisor of \emph{a} and \emph{b}. Then show
that $\displaystyle ab = md$. (Hint: use the prime factorization of
\emph{a} and \emph{b}.)
statement_raw: Let ''a'' and ''b'' denote positive integers. Let ''m'' denote the least common multiple of ''a'' and ''b'', and let ''d'' denote the greatest common divisor of ''a'' and ''b''. Then show that <math> \displaystyle ab = md </math>. (Hint: use the prime factorization of ''a'' and ''b''.)
